content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">     <idinfo>         <citation>             <citeinfo>                 <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>                 <pubdate>200412</pubdate>                 <title>USGS map quadrangles</title>                 <geoform>map</geoform>                 <pubinfo>                     <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>                     <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>                 </pubinfo>                 <onlink>http://mrdata.usgs.gov/reference/quad24.zip</onlink>             </citeinfo>         </citation>         <descript>             <abstract>USGS map quandrangle boundaries with names and unique identifiers for the 1:24,000 (7.5 minute) quadrangles.  Additional attributes provide unique identifiers and hierarchical relationships between these quadrangles and the enclosing 1:100,000 (30 x 60 minute) and 1:250,000 (1 x 2 degree) quadrangles.</abstract>             <purpose>The data set is intended to facilitate georeferencing scientific sampling localities by providing a named and coded reference system with which some people may already be familiar.</purpose>         </descript>         <timeperd>             <timeinfo>                 <mdattim>                     <sngdate>                         <caldate>20020204</caldate>                     </sngdate>                     <sngdate>                         <caldate>200412</caldate>                     </sngdate>                 </mdattim>             </timeinfo>             <current>Early reference is the last-modified date of a file that might have been the source of these data; later reference is the last modified date for these data.</current>         </timeperd>         <status>             <progress>Complete</progress>             <update>As needed</update>         </status>         <spdom>             <bounding>                 <westbc>-160.283342</westbc>                 <eastbc>-66.874999</eastbc>                 <northbc>49.499996</northbc>                 <southbc>18.873871</southbc>             </bounding>         </spdom>         <keywords>             <theme>                 <themekt>USGS Thesaurus</themekt>                 <themekey>geospatial datasets</themekey>                 <themekey>gazetteers</themekey>                 <themekey>culture and demographics</themekey>                 <themekey>maps and atlases</themekey>             </theme>             <theme> States</placekey>             </place>         </keywords>         <accconst>none</accconst>         <useconst>none</useconst>         <ptcontac>             <cntinfo>                 <cntperp>                     <cntper>Peter N Schweitzer</cntper>                     <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey, ER</cntorg>                 </cntperp>                 <cntpos>Geologist</cntpos>                 <cntaddr>                     <addrtype>mailing address</addrtype>                     <address>Mail Stop 954 12201 Sunrise Valley Drive</address>                     <city>Reston</city>                     <state>VA</state>                     <postal>20192</postal>                     <country>USA</country>                 </cntaddr>                 <cntvoice>703-648-6533</cntvoice>                 <cntfax>703-648-6252</cntfax>                 <cntemail>pschweitzer@usgs.gov</cntemail>             </cntinfo>         </ptcontac>         <datacred>Jeff Grossman created the coding scheme relating quadrangles of various scales</datacred>         <native>Originally creating using ArcView 3.3</native>     </idinfo>     <dataqual>         <attracc>             <attraccr>Names of the quads were given in the source data; rare corrections have been made where noticed.  Codes are mostly calculated from the coordinates but in some cases were created by examining the published (paper) quad map indexes produced by USGS on a state-by-state basis.</attraccr>         </attracc>         <logic>As far as is practical, the names match those given in the printed (paper) map indexes produced by USGS.  The numerical codes for the 1:250,000-scale quadrangles differ from those shown in some USGS map indexes because the point of reference is here taken as the northwest rather than the southeast corner of the quadrangle.</logic>         <complete>All 1:24,000 quadrangles currently available (as of 2004) were included.</complete>         <posacc>             <horizpa>                 <horizpar>Coordinate values are normally computed rather than measured.</horizpar>             </horizpa>         </posacc>         <lineage>             <srcinfo>                 <srccite>                     <citeinfo>                         <pubdate>2002</pubdate>                         <title>USGS 24K Quad Grid</title>                         <geoform>map</geoform>                         <othercit>Digital file taken, we believe, from www.gisdatadepot.com some time in 2003</othercit>                         <onlink>ftp://download1.geocomm.com/sd2/usgs_24kgrid.zip</onlink>                     </citeinfo>                 </srccite>                 <srcscale>24000</srcscale>                 <typesrc>digital data</typesrc>                 <srctime>                     <timeinfo>                         <sngdate>                             <caldate>20020204</caldate>                         </sngdate>                     </timeinfo>                     <srccurr>last-modified date of the data files</srccurr>                 </srctime>                 <srccitea>quad boundary data file</srccitea>                 <srccontr>Quadrangle boundaries and names</srccontr>             </srcinfo>             <procstep>                 <procdesc>Calculations of quad identification codes and correction of names where appropriate.  Addition of numerous attributes that permit hierarchical indexing of quads to be done without coordinate calculations (that is, by using database lookups).</procdesc>                 <srcused>quad boundary data file</srcused>                 <procdate>200412</procdate>                 <proccont>                     <cntinfo>                         <cntperp>                             <cntper>Jeffrey N Grossman</cntper>                             <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey, ER</cntorg>                         </cntperp>                         <cntaddr> <cntvoice>703-648-6184</cntvoice>                         <cntfax>703-648-6383</cntfax>                         <cntemail>jgrossman@usgs.gov</cntemail>                     </cntinfo>                 </proccont>             </procstep>         </lineage>     </dataqual>     <spdoinfo>         <direct>Vector</direct>         <ptvctinf>             <sdtsterm>                 <sdtstype>GT-polygon composed of chains</sdtstype>                 <ptvctcnt>53984</ptvctcnt>             </sdtsterm>         </ptvctinf>     </spdoinfo>     <spref>         <horizsys>             <geograph>                 <latres>0.125</latres>                 <longres>0.125</longres>                 <geogunit>Decimal degrees</geogunit>             </geograph>             <geodetic>                 <horizdn>North American Datum of 1983</horizdn>                 <ellips>Geodetic Reference System 80</ellips>                 <semiaxis>6378137</semiaxis>                 <denflat>298.257</denflat>             </geodetic>         </horizsys>     </spref>     <eainfo>         <detailed>             <enttyp>                 <enttypl>quad24.dbf</enttypl>                 <enttypd>Quadrangle</enttypd>             </enttyp>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>QUAD24_ID</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Unique integer identifier, not otherwise meaningful</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <rdom>                         <rdommin>1</rdommin>                         <rdommax>54079</rdommax>                         <attrunit>nominal</attrunit>                         <attrmres>1</attrmres>                     </rdom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>Q24CODE</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Unique meaningful code of the form AABBBCCXY, where AA is the 2-digit integer north latitude and BBB the integer west longitude of the northwest corner of the quadrangle, CC a quadrant designation (NE,SE, NW,SE, with a few other possible values), X is typically a letter from A through H and Y a number from 1 through 4.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <udom>The codes are all distinct.</udom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>Q100COD</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Unique identifier for the 1:100,000-scale quadrangle of which this 1:24,000-scale quadrangle is a part.  The value is a subset of that given in Q24CODE, of the form AABBBCC, where AA is the 2-digit integer north latitude and BBB the integer west longitude of the northwest corner of the quadrangle, CC a quadrant designation (NE,SE, NW,SE, with a few other possible values).</attrdef>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>Q250COD</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Unique identifier for the 1:250,000-scale quadrangle of which this 1:24,000-scale quadrangle is a part.  The value is a subset of that given in Q24CODE, of the form AABBB, where AA is the 2-digit integer north latitude and BBB the integer west longitude of the northwest corner of the quadrangle.</attrdef>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>QUAD24NAME</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Name of the 1:24,000-scale quadrangle map.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <udom>Place names not otherwise abbreviated.</udom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>QUAD24NAM2</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Name of the 1:24,000-scale quadrangle map followed by the 2-letter abbreviation(s) of the state or states the quad subtends.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <udom>Place names not otherwise abbreviated.</udom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>QUAD100NAM</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Name of the 1:100,000-scale quadrangle map.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <udom>Place names not otherwise abbreviated.</udom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>QUAD250NAM</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Name of the 1:250,000-scale quadrangle map.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <udom>Place names not otherwise abbreviated.</udom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>STATE1</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>2-letter abbreviation of one of the states the quadrangle overlaps.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <codesetd>                         <codesetn>Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas; (Federal Information Processing  Standard (FIPS) 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.</codesetn>                         <codesets>U.S. Department of Commerce</codesets>                     </codesetd>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>STATE2</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>2-letter abbreviation of one of the states the quadrangle overlaps.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <codesetd>                         <codesetn>Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas; (Federal Information Processing  Standard (FIPS) 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.</codesetn>                         <codesets>U.S. Department of Commerce</codesets>                     </codesetd>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>STATE3</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>2-letter abbreviation of one of the states the quadrangle overlaps.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <codesetd>                         <codesetn>Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas; (Federal Information Processing  Standard (FIPS) 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.</codesetn>                         <codesets>U.S. Department of Commerce</codesets>                     </codesetd>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>STATE4</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>2-letter abbreviation of one of the states the quadrangle overlaps.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <codesetd>                         <codesetn>Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas; (Federal Information Processing  Standard (FIPS) 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.</codesetn>                         <codesets>U.S. Department of Commerce</codesets>                     </codesetd>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>X</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Longitude value of the northwest corner of the quadrangle</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <rdom>                         <rdommin>-160.16000</rdommin>                         <rdommax>-66.93750</rdommax>                         <attrunit>decimal degrees</attrunit>                         <attrmres>0.125</attrmres>                     </rdom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>Y</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Latitude value of the northwest corner of the quadrangle</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <rdom>                         <rdommin>18.94000</rdommin>                         <rdommax>49.43750</rdommax>                         <attrunit>decimal degrees</attrunit>                         <attrmres>0.125</attrmres>                     </rdom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>CORNER</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Quadrant or part of the 1:250,000 quadrangle in which this 1:24,000 quadrangle lies.  In some coastal areas these do not correspond to compass directions but represent some other division of the space.</attrdef>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>CE</edomv>                         <edomvd>Center east (coastal area)</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>         </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>NW</edomv>                         <edomvd>Northwest quarter</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>NX</edomv>                         <edomvd>North part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>NY</edomv>                         <edomvd>North part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>SE</edomv>                         <edomvd>Southeast quarter</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom> <edom>                         <edomv>SS</edomv>                         <edomvd>South half of south half</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv> <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>SX</edomv>                         <edomvd>South part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>SY</edomv>                         <edomvd>South part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>XE</edomv>                         <edomvd>East part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>XW</edomv>                         <edomvd>West part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>                 <attrdomv>                     <edom>                         <edomv>YW</edomv>                         <edomvd>West part of a quad in a coastal area</edomvd>                     </edom>                 </attrdomv>             </attr>             <attr>                 <attrlabl>CELL</attrlabl>                 <attrdef>Two-letter (or more commonly a letter followed by a number) code indicating the position within the 1:100,000-scale quadrangle of the 1:24,000-scale quadrangle.  Cell A1 is in the northwest corner of the larger quadrangle; cell A4 is in the southwest corner, cell H1 is in the northeast corner, and cell H4 is in the southeast corner.  The only unusual value is X1.</attrdef>             </attr>         </detailed>     </eainfo>     <distinfo>         <distrib>             <cntinfo>                 <cntperp>
